content:
Fun problem, but maybe not suited for Shortest mode.

I played this in Shortest mode. One of the other clashers dropped out and all the others got 0% after 15 minutes. I'm the only one who finished.

Suggestion: for Shortest mode, treat the whole input as a whole word. Don't make us split the input into words and solve the problem separately for each word. That's just an uninteresting extra layer of complication for no reason.

Your solution has 291 characters in Python. Usually, good shortest mode clashes can be done in less than 100. I personally don't think shortest mode is something everyone should just throw in for every clash they submit for no reason.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, with difficulty level well balanced, easy but not obvious.
All tests are ok for me now, and as you've removed the Reverse Mode I think there's no reason to not approve it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like this clash! And I think that a Reverse mode won't be too difficult, especially if you add some more obvious tests (similar to Test 4), for example 'abcde'
I think this clash is ok for Fastest and Shortest, but to difficult in Reverse mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is easy, quite well explained and very unique. Overall, I think it will be great for a CoC.
You should explain what precedence means, because some people might not understand what to do.
Thanks for the feedback. I've added an example in the statement for clarification, please let me know what you think.

Thanks for your feedback. Honestly originally it was meant for Reverse mode, I thought that by looking at the first three examples it would be fairly quick to figure out the pattern, but I didn't realize that it could be too difficult. Do you think I should simplify the first examples a little bit more?

Why do you expect the solution provided here to be exclusively for Shortest mode when the clash is also for Fastest? The solution provided here has obviously that much characters to provide readability for contributors (as you could have concluded by just seeing variable names!)
It is up to the Clashers to make it less when it's a Shortest mode clash, that's the point of the challenge. If this was a challenge I could make it more than 50% less the amount of characters it has now, but it's not, it's a contribution!

Well, I don't go around checking the lengths of the solutions for all shortest mode clashes. I checked because it didn't seem very appropriate for shortest mode to me. Extensive string parsing and output formatting, for instance. Different types of input characters treated differently, requiring explicit conditions.
I don't expect the solution to be "exclusively" for shortest mode; but it does seem to me that most contributors simply check shortest mode without giving any thought to what it actually entails. I think shortest mode puzzles that can't be made short are simply not as good as ones that can. There are hundreds of them on CG, so IMO Shortest mode puzzles should be specifically made to be interesting in Shortest mode.

Well, it would be better if there were precise rules about that, because "interesting" can be defined differently from one person to another, I could solve this challenge in a one liner, though a bit more than 100 bytes, and it would be "interesting" for me to see someone do it in less, but AFAIK there is no rule that says "it should be able to be solved with less than 100 bytes... in Python", and even if there was, we wouldn't be able to tell if it could be done or not, because there is always that person who comes with a better, more clever method, and that's the fun of it in my opinion.
Fair enough. I'm subjective, no doubt. I like some puzzles more than others. I did work on this until I ran out of time, but I also think that I would have approached it differently in Fastest mode.
Hello! I've added some more text cases that would clarify the problem for Reverse Mode. Looking forward to your feedback!

I don't remember what were the previous tests cases,  I think it is still  a difficult clash in Reverse mode ,.
I've tested it and I almost did it in 6 minutes.
I still have errors for test 6:
bullshit!  in your test became 18446237!  why there's no 5 in this solution, did I make a mistake ? for me it should be : 17445236!

for similar reason (digit missing in your answer) I don't pass test and validations 5 and 7

here my solution:
s = input()
r = []
for w in s.lower().split():
    d = {}; t=''; i=0
    for c in sorted({*w}):
        if c.isalpha():
            i+=1
            d[c] = str(i)
        else:
            d[c] = c
    r += [''.join(map(d.get,w))]

print(*r)

You're right, I made an oopsie! In my previous solution I had a mistake where, when I take a word and make it into a sorted list of characters (so that I could get their indexes afterwards), I forgot to remove the doubled characters, so the characters that came after them ended up having indexes bigger than they were supposed to (so the 's' in 'bullshit' got 6 instead of 5 because of the 'll' and so on):

```
s = input()

answer = []
for word in s.lower().split():
    sorted_letters = sorted([c for c in word if c.isalpha()])
    new_word = ''
    for char in word:
        new_word += (char if not char.isalpha()
                    else str(sorted_letters.index(char) + 1))
    answer += [new_word]
print(*answer)
```

So I just had to feed it to a set right before I sorted it, just like you did:

```
sorted_letters = sorted(set([c for c in word if c.isalpha()]))
```

So it should be OK now, I really appreciate your feedback and testing, it was very helpful! Thanks a lot.

And I've removed Reverse mode since I've realized that like you said, the clash is hard enough for Fastest/Shortest modes.
